subject: US MARKET WRAP: Stocks print fresh highs despite NFP miss
content:
NONFARM PAYROLLS: Headline miss, AHE in line

The dollar sank, and Treasuries were heavily bid after December’s nonfarm payrolls data missed expectations. Equities fell, though were more resilient, paring back the knee-jerk losses post the data release.

While the headline was a miss, the average hourly earnings data were in line with expectations, and do little to shift the Fed hike narrative. Indeed, many analysts expect that, as the US makes further ground in full-employment territory, headline payroll growth will slow, and many think that as that happens, wage pressures will be stoked.  

FEDSPEAK: Harker, Mester, Bullard made comments on Friday

Fed’s Mester (voter): Mester would be happy with three/four hikes in 2018 (the FOMC’s ‘dots’ look for three hikes). She was encouraged by the “strong” US Employment Situation Report for December, and argued that the economic expansion was firmly in place. Mester sees inflation rising to target in 2019.

Fed’s Harker (non-voter): The dollar eased slightly after 2017 voter Harker said that two rate hikes would be appropriate in 2018 (the ‘dots’ have pencilled in three hikes). The comments were surprising given that Harker was previously considered one of the hawkish members of the FOMC; he cited the lack of wages pressure as a reason for his caution.

Fed’s Bullard (non-voter): Bullard repeated his recent view that the Fed should 'wait and see' regarding further rate hikes, arguing that the central bank has made no progress towards inflation since 2015.

EQUITIES: SPX +0.7% at 2,742; DJI +0.8% at 25,284; NDX +1.0% at 6,550
Top performing sectors: IT +1.1%, Healthcare +0.9%, Materials +0.8%
Bottom performing sectors: Energy -0.1%, Utilities 0.0%, Telecoms 0.0%

Equity traders were happy to look through the headline weakness in the Employment Situation Report, with S&P 500 eminis finishing positive every day this week.

Tech lead the advance. Energy lagged, however, tracking crude prices, after traders took profits on the black stuff following the recent rally in prices.

It is expected that trade may pick up next week as earnings season gets underway, and the big banks begin reporting their numbers.

TREASURIES: US 10-Year T-Note Futures settled 5 ticks lower at 123-16+

The US Treasury yields were on Friday, with the curve mildly bear-steepening. Despite headline payrolls disappointing, the wages data continue to point to growth, albeit at a subdued rate when compared to previous recoveries. The data did little to suggest the Fed will alter course, and in combination with optimism about the impact of tax reform, traders were content to end the week selling Treasuries.

Next week’s CPI, PPI and retail sales data will help shape traders’ expectations with regards to more immediate rate hikes. On Friday, the probability of a January hike remained beneath 1%: the chance of March hike were at 80%, the chance of seeing two hikes by June is around 50/50, and there is around 30% chance of three hikes by the end of the year, according to the CME’s Fedwatch tool.

FOREX:

While the DXY was modestly up on the day, the dollar index is more-or-less unchanged in the week. The buck saw heavy losses against the CAD following an NFP miss in combination with a stellar Canadian employment report, sending USDCAD crashing through 1.25 to lows near 1.2360 before recovering to 1.24.

The Eurozone CPI reported for December was in line with expectations, falling 0.1ppts to 1.4%, as expected; the core rate was unchanged at 0.9%. There was little market reaction. The single currency jumped towards 1.2085 following the US payrolls miss, though the gains were pared back as traders digested the data. Either way, the key 1.20 handle remains the focus, with the EUR consolidating above the level in the first week of 2018 trade.

Safe havens were red on Friday, with the yen and Swissy down against most of the majors, while gold was slightly negative, settling around the $1320 mark. Firm equities, negative Treasuries, and a resilient risk tone helped to buoy the EMFX complex slightly.

The pound was uneventful on Friday; in thin news, the 1.36 handle is in focus to the top side, though sterling seems to have been more driven by USD factors this week. Against the EUR, the pound did carve out gains. The next catalysts may come via next week’s industrial and manufacturing production data, though traders will be on the look-out for Brexit-related newsflow over the weekend following comments from the EU’s Juncker, who was quoted as saying that Brexit talks will be ‘exceptionally difficult’.  

CRUDE: WTI futures settle 57 cents lower at $61.44 per barrel; Brent future settle 45 cents lower at USD 67.62 per barrel

WTI closed red for the first time in six sessions, with profit-taking being cited after the rally that began in mid-December. On the week, however, crude is positive, adding around $1.50 in the first trading week of the year.

Traders were banking some of their recent gains after US President Donald Trump on Thursday proposed repealing the ban on offshore drilling, though even some Republican Senators have expressed opposition.

Separately, a study by Rystad Energy has found that global oil discoveries declined to an all-time low in 2017.

content:

- Fed should keep powder dry until it is clear what the impact of tax reform will be
- Sees significant signs of economic overheating
- Says Fed should avoid any action that highlights the risk of an inverted yield curve

subject: FX Weekly Wrap: Dollar displaying some resilience despite US payroll miss
content:
DXY

The Greenback is staging an impressive attempt to recoup initial post-NFP losses and close out a weak first week of 2018 off worst levels, with the Index straddling 92.000. Usd bulls and shorts are looking beyond the headline jobs miss at other components (wages and unemployment rate for example) that matched consensus and on balance should not deflect the Fed from its rate (hike) path this year, especially with a more hawkish-leaning voting panel. A close above the big figure or even 91.988 (76.4% Fib) could yield further recovery gains towards 93.720 resistance, but a failure to hold this week’s circa 91.750 lows would suggest ongoing declines.

CAD

The clear G10 outperformer on another whopping 70k+ monthly Canadian employment gain that beat +1k expectations by a mile and boosted January BoC tightening prospects to over 60%, per OIS calculations. The Loonie soared as a result with Usd/Cad down to 1.2355 from around 1.2500 before the US unit regained some composure, but 1.2336 chart support remains far more compelling than 1.2400.

NZD

The Kiwi also looking to build on recent gains vs its US counterpart having breached some key chart resistance levels since the start of 2018, and tripping stops between 0.7165-70 (Fib level) on the way to a 0.7186-7 high. Nearest bullish tech/psychological objective now 0.7200, with more buy orders reportedly in place on a clear break.

GBP/EUR

Holding up well vs the Usd and a net gainer on the week, albeit off 1.3600+ best levels within a 1.3525-80 range. Sterling also outpacing the Eur in late trade, as Eur/Gbp slips back under 0.8900 and Eur/Usd revisits lows of the week near 1.2000 after failing (again) to seriously test last year’s high (1.2092), which is stalling further upside potential.

JPY

One of the only Greenback underperformers on Friday and the week overall, undermined by broad risk-on sentiment. Usd/Jpy marginally extended topside ranges to 113.30 and closer to the next offer zone from 113.40-50, while Jpy crosses also rallied.

subject: Barclays US Q4 GDP tracker 2.5% (Prev. 2.6%) citing wider-than-expected November trade deficit
Fed's Harker says two hikes in 2018 is appropriate
content:
Says:

- Could be time to reevaluate how Fed conducts policy, though not advocating a specific change.

- If soft inflation continues, it may make 2% target harder to reach. 

- Wage increases are not what you would expect given the current labour market
analysis_details: - Harker is not a voter in 2018 but has typically been seen as one of the more hawkish members so these comments are more dovish than usual.

subject: CBS (CBS) All Access has launched ability for Amazon (AMZN) Prime members to add CBS channels to Prime membership

content: OPEC members who are subject to supply cuts achieve 128% compliance in December (November 125%)

subject: WH Economic Advisor Cohn says the stock market is not expensive at the moment
WH Economic Advisor Cohn says he sees the economy continuously growing and adding jobs and that he doesn’t think there’s a need to get used to jobs numbers below 200k
content: - US should see real wages growing

subject: Markets are continuing to see a reversal of their post-NFP moves with USD gaining ground and USTs moving lower as markets assess the implications for Fed policy in what was overall a neutral report
analysis_details: - In terms of a Fed perspective, given the headline missed BUT was subject to an upward revision and earnings were in-line, overall this may not provide too much sway on future FOMC thought, particularly given the total composition of the Fed for 2018 is yet to be known. In fact expectations are for a more hawkish Fed who may chose to look through a headline of 148k which is still solid jobs growth and comes in the context of months of 200k+ readings.

subject: Fixed Income: firmer across the board post-NFP, but not NA border
content: Core EU bonds have rallied (understandably) on the headline NFP miss, with Bunds up to 161.87 and Gilts to 124.90 alongside USTs, before running out of steam (as other components of the NFP report were in line or upbeat, but not enough to over shadow the disappointment). Eurozone peripheral debt is also extending gains having erased relative declines ahead of the US jobs data, but in stark contrast Cad bonds and BAX futures have dropped in response to the 2nd stellar Canadian employment report that has lifted near term BoC rate hike prospects, naturally (now 60%+ for the January policy meeting).

content:
5th January 2018

EARNINGS

Constellation Brands (STZ) – Q1 (USD) Comparable EPS 2.00 vs Exp. 1.87, Net Sales 1.799bln vs Exp. 1.68bln. Further, the co. announces a 3bln buyback programme and forecasts 2018 Comparable EPS at 8.40 – 8.50 vs Exp. 8.43. (Newswires)  

 

DJIA

Apple (AAPL) – The tech giants support page notes the issue that researchers have uncovered security issues known by Meltdown and Spectre which applies to all modern processors and affect nearly all computing devices and operating systems. Further, the co sees product delays under leadership from CEO Tim Cook. Separately, Jimme Iovine, who sold Beats to the co., is to leave Apple Music. (Newswires / WSJ / Billboard)

Intel (INTC) – Tech companies have said that Intel’s chips are only slowing down computers slightly. Further, the chipmaker has struggled with chip exploits for months. (WSJ)

Pfizer (PFE) – Distributed Bio announces a SuperHuman Platform license agreement with the healthcare giant. (Newswires)

 

S&P 500

Airline Names (AAL, DAL, JBLU, LUV, UAL) – There have been over 600 flights cancelled due to the winter storm. (CNBC)

CenterPoint Energy (CNP) – The co. announces its five-year investment plan will total USD 8.3bln. (Newswires)

CVS Health (CVS) / Aetna (AET) – The US Department of Justice are reviewing the deal between the two companies. (Newswires)

Mallinckrodt (MNK) – The pharmaceutical co. announces it has successfully completed the New Drug Application to the FDA for its Stannsoporfin. (Newswires)

Morgan Stanley (MS) – The bank estimates net income for the Quarter ending December 31st will include an aggregate net discrete tax provision of roughly USD 1.25bln. (Newswires)

ONEOK (OKE) – The co. plans to invest USD 1.4bln to construct a new pipeline. (Newswires)

Target (TGT) – Barclays raise the co. price target to USD 70 from USD 45. (Newswires)

 

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOG) – The tech giant announces it is making an investment into a Chinese E-Sports start up, Chushou. (TechCrunch)

Amazon (AMZN) – Recode notes that whilst there is speculation the retail giant may purchase Nordstrom (JWN) or Target (TGT), it may move to ‘big products’. Separately, Citi have raised the retailers price target to USD 1400 from 1250. (Newswires/Recode)

Qualcomm (QCOM) – Sony’s mid-range phones will be using the co.’s processors. (Newswires)

 

OTHER NEWS

AveXis (AVXS) – The co. has aligned with the FDA on its next step in a Biologics License Application submission for its AVXS-101. (Newswires)

Hain Celestial (HAIN) – The co. is unable to find a buyer after being informally on sale for about a year due to a brand overload. (NY Post)

LGI Homes (LGI) – The co. reported a record amount of 770 house closings during December. (Newswires)

Novartis (NVS) – The pharmaceutical co. is said to consider selling more US generic assets, which could fetch up to USD 3bln. (Newswires)  

Teva (TEVA) – The pharmaceutical co. has reached an agreement with unions on headquarter layoffs. (Globes)

DAILY US OPENING NEWS - Eyes on NFP as Eurozone inflation slows to 1.4%
content:
5th January 2018

  • European equities higher, led by auto names after a number of broker upgrades in the sector
  • Eurozone CPI slows to 1.4%, in line with expectations
  • Highlights include US and Canadian jobs reports, US durable goods orders and ISM non-manufacturing

ASIA

Asia-Pac equities closed the week out on a high, following yet another day of gains in the US, whereby the DJIA broke 25k for the first time. Strong data out of the US boosted sentiment with the ADP figure beating analysts’ estimates, hinting at a firm number in today’s US NFP report. ASX 200 (+0.7%) continued to make fresh 10yr highs with the index finding support from financial and mining stocks. Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) had its best two day gain since November and probed 26yr highs amid the rise in banking stocks, while Chinese markets also posted gains (Shanghai Comp +0.2%, Hang Seng Index +0.3%).

US

No major stories of note from the US

Please click here for a preview of December’s Nonfarm Payrolls report

EU/UK

Eurozone CPI Prelim Y/Y (Dec) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.5%)

Eurozone Core CPI Prelim Y/Y (Dec) 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.1%)

German Retail Sales M/M (Nov) 2.3% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. -1.2%)

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Dec) Y/Y -0.6% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

South Korea's unification ministry said North Korea has accepted an offer for talks on January 9th, with the agenda on Winter Olympics and other mutual interests. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.5%) are trading higher across the board in the wake of another upbeat Asia-Pac session which saw the Nikkei 225 print its best two-day gain since November. In terms of sector performance, auto names are performing well with Volkswagen (+2.7%), Peugeot (+2.7%) and Fiat Chrysler (+3.2%) all top of the DAX, CAC 40 and FTSE MIB respectively following a slew of broker upgrades at JP Morgan with utility names, Centrica (+1.9%) and United Utilities (+1.4%) at the top of the FSTE 100 following broker upgrades at Credit Suisse. Elsewhere, Dialog Semiconductor (-3.7%) shares are lagging their peers in the wake of reports that Apple products have been hit by chip flaws.

FX

In FX markets, AUD/USD one of the big movers overnight, with the pair recoiling from 0.7870 to a 0.7835 low on the back of Aussie trade data showing a deficit vs expected surplus as exports completely stagnated. Elsewhere, broad risk appetite, as Wall Street sets more all-time records and global stocks continue to rally, has undermined the traditional safe-haven currencies, and with the JPY also losing ground amidst decent cross-related flows (ie EUR/JPY bids said to be targeting 140.00 from around 136.50 currently). NZD/CAD/GBP/EUR are all holding up relatively well vs the USD as the DXY attempts to stay within touching distance of the 92.000 handle ahead of today’s US jobs report.

FIXED INCOME

Trading volumes remain paltry even by normal pre-US jobs data standards (although MiFiD 2 and tighter Chinese bond market rules may help to explain low turnover), but there have been some decent moves, disconnects and distortions. Gilts have confounded the weaker or indifferent impulses seen ahead of the Liffe open to push ahead from the off (aside from a brief 2 tick stutter below parity), and printed at 124.88 for a 23 tick gain on what appears to be at least corrective due to their earlier closing time. Nevertheless, Bunds have caught a bid to register a fresh Eurex peak as well, at 161.74 (+15 ticks vs -9 ticks at the other extreme), after holding in at the 50% retracement support level. 161.82-86 forms the next tech resistance area, while bears will still be eyeing 161.36 ahead of Thursday’s 161.26 low and the 161.18 ultimate downside target that has survived several times. US Treasuries marginally weaker pre-NFP, aside from flat 2 year notes as the curve steadies a tad following the most recent bout of flattening.

 

COMMODITIES

In the energy complex, both WTI and Brent crude futures are seen lower as markets take a breather from the recent rally which had lifted prices to multi-year highs with some profit-taking potentially entering the market. In terms of energy newsflow, things remain on the light side but markets remain sensitive to events in Iran and any potential backlash from the US via sanctions. In metals markets, gold prices have been seen lower overnight amid touted profit-taking, albeit prices remain in close proximity to recent highs. Elsewhere, Chinese steel futures were seen lower overnight as weather concerns continue to sway prices whilst Zinc (highest since mid-2007) remains supported in London amid supply fears.

subject: Mixed EZ data – muted market response
content: Only minimal movement in Bunds (down less than a handful of ticks) and the Eur (up 5 pips or so vs the Usd) to the preliminary Eurozone inflation report for December that was in line with consensus on the headline and pretty mixed in terms of the core depending what measure you look at. For the record, the 10 year German benchmark is currently around 161.70 vs 161.77 at best, and Eur/Usd just below 1.2050 within a 1.2042-80 range ahead of the potentially if not probably much more market-moving release (NFP) later. Technically, or chart-wise, a US jobs data surprise could bring into play 161.18 or 162.00+ for Bunds, and 1.2000, 1.1970-60 to 1.2090-1.2100 for Eur/Usd.

subject: BAML Flow Show:
content: - USD 4.5bln outflows from equities this week vs USD 14.4bln inflows last week; USD 9.2bln inflows to bonds this week, adding to USD 1.2bln inflows last week; choppy year-end stuff but takeaway is bond inflows (big into IG & EM and 1st HY inflows in 10 weeks).

subject: EU Infl Exenerfoodalctob YY (Dec) 0.9% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 0.9%)
EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: European bourses higher once again as attention now turns to December’s US jobs report

In terms of sector performance, auto names are performing well with Volkswagen (+2.7%), Peugeot (+2.7%) and Fiat Chrysler (+3.2%) all top of the DAX, CAC 40 and FTSE MIB respectively following a slew of broker upgrades at JP Morgan with utility names, Centrica (+1.9%) and United Utilities (+1.4%) at the top of the FSTE 100 following broker upgrades at Credit Suisse. Elsewhere, Dialog Semiconductor (-3.7%) shares are lagging their peers in the wake of reports that Apple products have been hit by chip flaws.

In FX markets, AUD/USD one of the big movers overnight, with the pair recoiling from 0.7870 to a 0.7835 low on the back of Aussie trade data showing a deficit vs expected surplus as exports completely stagnated. Elsewhere, broad risk appetite, as Wall Street sets more all-time records and global stocks continue to rally, has undermined the traditional safe-haven currencies, and with the JPY also losing ground amidst decent cross-related flows (ie EUR/JPY bids said to be targeting 140.00 from around 136.50 currently). NZD/CAD/GBP/EUR are all on the firmer side or at least holding up well vs the USD as the DXY attempts to stay within touching distance of the 92.000 handle ahead of today’s US jobs report.

Gilts have confounded the weaker or indifferent impulses seen ahead of the Liffe open to push ahead from the off (aside from a brief 2 tick stutter below parity), and just printed at 124.88 for a 23 tick gain on what appears to be at least corrective due to their earlier closing time. US Treasuries marginally weaker pre-NFP, aside from flat 2 year notes as the curve steadies a tad following the most recent bout of flattening.

In the energy complex, both WTI and Brent crude futures are seen lower as markets take a breather from the recent rally which had lifted prices to multi-year highs with some profit-taking potentially entering the market. In terms of energy newsflow, things remain on the light side but markets remain sensitive to events in Iran and any potential backlash from the US via sanctions. subject: UK labour productivity, as measured by output per hour, is estimated to have grown by 0.9% from Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2017 to Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2017; this is the largest increase in productivity since Quarter 2 2011
content:
Labour productivity grew in both the services and manufacturing industries; services productivity grew by 1.0% on the previous quarter, and manufacturing productivity also grew by 1.0%.

Earnings and other labour costs growth outpaced productivity growth, resulting in unit labour cost (ULC) growth of 1.3% in the year to Quarter 3 2017, the lowest ULC growth since Quarter 2 2015

subject: Fixed Income: flighty, choppy and thin trade persists
content: Trading volumes remain paltry even by normal pre-US jobs data standards (although MiFiD 2 and tighter Chinese bond market rules may help to explain low turnover), but there have been some decent moves, disconnects and distortions. Gilts have confounded the weaker or indifferent impulses seen ahead of the Liffe open to push ahead from the off (aside from a brief 2 tick stutter below parity), and just printed at 124.88 for a 23 tick gain on what appears to be at least corrective due to their earlier closing time. subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION
ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION
FX Morning Colour: Aud, Jpy and Chf buck stronger G10 trend vs Usd
content:
AUD

Aud/Usd one of the big movers overnight, with the pair recoiling from 0.7870 to a 0.7835 low on the back of Aussie trade data showing a deficit vs expected surplus as exports completely stagnated. However, Aud bulls are encouraged by the fact that support just ahead and below the 0.7800 level has not been threatened or indeed tested, with offers seen around 0.7900 still eyed on the upside.

JPY/CHF

Broad risk appetite, as Wall Street sets more all time records and global stocks continue to rally, has undermined the traditional safe-haven currencies, and with the Jpy also losing ground amidst decent cross-related flows (ie Eur/Jpy bids said to be targeting 140.00 from around 136.50 currently). Usd/Jpy has subsequently breached a key Fib just below 113.00 to trade up near 113.20, and with chart stochastics now bullish within a higher range towards the next major resistance area between 113.64-75. Usd/Chf back near the top of a broad 0.9700-0.9800 range, and like all FX majors looking at NFP for the next big move.

NZD/CAD/GBP/EUR

All on the firmer side or at least holding up well vs the Usd as the DXY attempts to stay within touching distance of the 92.000 handle. The Kiwi is nestling at 0.7150 having cleared key resistance at 0.7132, with the next key tech upside objectives at 0.7169 before 0.7203 (latter strong and obviously close to the psychological big figure). Usd/Cad back above 1.2500, just, also eyeing oil prices and Canadian jobs data for independent Loonie direction. Cable remains stuck in 1.3500-1.3600 trading parameters, but Sterling is marginally softer vs the Eur (cross just over 0.8900 after a fixing squeeze yesterday), as Eur/Usd rebounds further above 1.2000 support to retest recent highs just below the 1.2092 peak from 2017.

subject: German Construction PMI (Dec) 53.7 (Prev. 53.1)
ECB says banks borrowed EUR 12mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 705.2bln

European equity movers: Centrica (CNA LN) +2.3%, Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) +1.9%, Peugeot (UG FP) +1.8%, Continental (CON GY) +1.4%, Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) +1.3%, United Utilities (UU/ LN) +1.3%, Adecco (ADEN SW) +1.2%, Admiral (ADM LN) -2.5%
UK STIR STRIP: erring on the side of caution
content: Short Sterling futures are on the defensive, albeit marginally lower for choice vs yesterday’s settlement levels and with turnover even lighter than they have been of late. There is nothing scheduled on the UK agenda today, and weak BRC shop prices overnight are largely discounted/dismissed given obvious concessions over the seasonal period. Nothing to trade off on the Brexit front either, as talks are not set to resume in earnest until later in 2018, hence it’s all about the first US employment update of the year. Indeed, external leads for Gilts appear indecisive so not much deviation off the open likely from Thursday’s 124.65 close.

subject: Option expiries of note for today's 10.00am NY cut (1500GMT)
Bunds: calm consolidation pre-Eurozone CPI data, and NFP
content: A modest uptick off the Eurex open in typically low-key trading conditions ahead of the monthly US jobs data, and with Eurozone inflation a realistic contender for headline event in the run up. The 10 year German bond is currently towards the bottom of a 161.59-70 early range vs Thursday’s 161.59 close with turnover only just exceeding 6.5k lots so far. So, very lacklustre in terms of direction, volume and even curve activity, though semi-core and peripheral debt has started Friday’s session on the back foot (albeit moderately) to unwind some of yesterday’s marked outperformance and spread narrowing. Yield-wise the 10 year German benchmark is hovering around 0.44% having just evaded a proper test of 0.5% earlier this week.

content:

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Sky (SKY LN)/BT (BT/A LN) – Amazon (AMZN) has held talks over the UK rights to show Premier League football
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

5th January 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac region closes the week out on a high, following yet another day of gains in the US, whereby the DJIA broke 25k for the first time. Strong data out of the US boosted sentiment with the ADP figure beating analysts’ estimates, hinting at a firm number in today’s US NFP report. ASX 200 (+0.7%) continues to make fresh 10yr highs with the index finding support from financial and mining stocks. Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) on course for its best two day gain since November and probed 26yr highs amid the rise in banking stocks, while Chinese markets put in a mixed performance (Shanghai Comp +0.1%, Hang Seng Index -0.1%).

FTSE

Sky (SKY LN)/BT (BT/A LN) – Amazon (AMZN) has held talks over the UK rights to show Premier League football. (Telegraph)

Retailers - UK BRC Shop Price Index (Dec) Y/Y -0.6% (Prev. -0.1%). Separately, a number of hedge funds have built up large short positions in UK retailers ahead of their Christmas trading updates. (FT)

Defence Names – UK ministers are planning to delay a spending review on national security and defence. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Ocado (OCDO LN) – Reports in Sweden suggest the co. is days away from sealing a deal with Nordic retailer ICA Gruppen. (Times)

NOKIAN TYRES (NRE1V FH) CUT TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN

HEXAGON (HEXAB SS) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

US

Another day of record highs, but today, the focus was on the Dow, which broke the 25,000 level for the first time, buoyed by API data which hints at a strong NFP print on Friday. Gains in US equities were broad based, with only the defensive utilities sector in the red. Macy’s, however, was down on the day after reporting disappointing holiday sales, which also weighed on some of its competitors’ it was a similar story at L Brands. Sprint was lower after announcing that former Altice CEO Combes has been appointed as CFO. SPX +0.4% at 2723, DJI +0.6% at 25073, NDX +0.1% at 6585

Top performers: Financials +0.9%, Materials +0.8%, Industrials +0.8%

Bottom performers: Utilities -0.9%, Healthcare +0.1%, Consumer Staples +0.2%

Apple (AAPL) – Co. has informed about speculative execution vulnerabilities in ARM-based and Intel CPUs and states that all Mac systems and IOS devices are affected, but there are no known exploits impacting customers. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asia-Pac region closes the week out on a high, following yet another day of gains in the US
content:
• Asia-Pac region closes the week out on a high, following yet another day of gains in the US
  • In FX, AUD slipped across the board after Aussie trade data showed a surprise deficit
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German retail sales, Eurozone inflation, US and Canadian jobs reports, US factory orders, ISM Non-Mfg

ASIA

Asia-Pac region closes the week out on a high, following yet another day of gains in the US, whereby the DJIA broke 25k for the first time. Strong data out of the US boosted sentiment with the ADP figure beating analysts’ estimates, hinting at a firm number in today’s US NFP report. ASX 200 (+0.7%) continues to make fresh 10yr highs with the index finding support from financial and mining stocks. Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) on course for its best two day gain since November and probed 26yr highs amid the rise in banking stocks, while Chinese markets put in a mixed performance (Shanghai Comp +0.1%, Hang Seng Index -0.1%).
 

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.4915 (Prev. 6.5043). (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Dec) Y/Y -0.6% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)

UK industry body SMMT says 2017 UK car sales fell by 5.6% (biggest drop since 2009), diesel car sales fell 17.1%. (Newswires)


FX

Price action had been somewhat rangebound which is typically the case ahead of the US Jobs report. AUD however, had been the noticeable mover, whereby the currency slipped across the board after Aussie trade data showed a surprise deficit. The USD remains tepid against its counterparts with exception of the JPY, dismissing strong a ADP figure with many investors remain cautious over the inflation outlook for the US. As such, investors are growing ever the more sceptical that the Fed will be able to maintain its projected path of interest rate hikes (3) for this year, which in turn has capped long term US yields. JPY off slightly with USD/JPY looking to make a move to test 113.00, interest rate differentials at play with the US/JP spread wider by 0.3bps, additionally the risk-on sentiment seen in global equities has also kept the pressure on the JPY.
 

COMMODITIES

Oil prices softened marginally but held near their highest levels since May 2015 with concerns about supply risks due to unrest in Iran, while US crude inventories should a decline amid refining activity hitting a 12yr high. In metals markets, gold prices have been seen lower overnight amid touted profit-taking, albeit prices remain in close proximity to recent highs. Elsewhere, zinc prices remain near multi-year highs as supply concerns continue to linger.

CME lower margin requirement for NYMEX crude oil futures by 7.1% to USD 1950 per contract. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

South Korea's unification ministry says North Korea accepts offer for talks on January 9th, with the agenda on winter Olympics and other mutual interests. (Newswires)
 

US

FIXED INCOME: 10-Year T-Note futures settle 3+ ticks lower at 123-21+

The Treasury complex took its cue from yesterday’s mildly hawkish FOMC meeting minutes, as well as a decent batch of labour market data, which raises hopes of a solid NFP print on Friday. Although Treasury yields are higher on the day – with the 2yr yield now within touching distance of 2% – most of the major curves had flattened once again. 2s10s, 2s30s and 5s30s all narrowed by c.2bps to c.2.5bps at settlement. Much of the curve is near or at the flattest levels in around a decade.

Apple (AAPL) informs about speculative execution vulnerabilities in Arm-based and Intel CPUs and states that all mac systems and IOS devices are affected, but there are no known exploits impacting customers. (Newswires)

subject: Fast Retailing (9983 JT) reports December Uniqlo sales rose 18.1% Y/Y
Houthis in Yemen is said to have fired a missile at military target in Saudi Arabia
Malaysian Trade Balance (Nov) M/M 9.95bln vs. Exp. 10.9bln (Prev. 10.6bln)
China issues rules for equity investment by insurance funds: to ban insurers from guaranteed return of equity on investments
Analysts at BofAML expect EUR/USD to weaken to 1.10 in Q1 2018, but then to gradually move towards its long-term equilibrium, 1.19 by end-2018 and 1.25 by end-2019
content:
1- EUR/USD has overshot the data.

 2- The market is long EUR and this position could be at risk.

 3-  Expect further Fed and ECB monetary policy divergence, which the market has yet to price for the Fed.

 4- The US tax reform will support the USD through fiscal stimulus and profit repatriation; market expectations remain too pessimistic in their view

content:
Asia-Pac region remains support by the record highs once again in the US which saw the DJIA breaching 25k for the first time. Strong data out of the US boosted sentiment with the ADP figure beating analysts estimates, hinting at a possibly strong number in today’s US NFP report. ASX 200 continues to make fresh 10yr highs with the index support by financial and mining stocks. Nikkei 225 on course for its best two day gain since November, while Chinese markets conform to the tone. 

AUD the noticeable mover thus far following a surprise deficit in the latest Trade Balance report, while the previous reported surplus had been revised to a deficit. Elsewhere, major FX pairs have been rangebound, as is typically the case before the US jobs figures.

subject: PREVIEW: Australian Trade Balance
content:
Australia's trade surplus in Oct narrowed to the smallest since Apr at AUD 0.105bn as exports saw a 3% m/m retreat against a 2% m/m gain in imports. The decline in base metal exports was the largest drag as metal ores retreated 10%, while metals slipped by 16%. Imports meanwhile were boosted by increased demand for consumption goods (2%).

Looking forward to Nov, trade surplus is expected to improve slightly to AUD 0.55B as exports to China is expected to pick up (China's Nov imports saw a 17.7%y/y increase to USD 177.11Bn, the largest since Sept) as energy companies increase purchases ahead of winter season that would typically see more heating. That said, although coal exports may recover, iron ore exports are expected to be lackluster as China clamps down on pollution during the winter season. For imports, the weaker Aussie over Oct/Nov would likely boost import receipts and narrow the surplus. Overall, while coal exports should improve, higher import receipts and still lackluster iron ore exports should keep surplus well below 2017's average of AUD 1.34bn.

subject: UK industry body SMMT says 2017 UK car sales fell by 5.6% (biggest drop since 2009), diesel car sales fell 17.1%
UK BRC Shop Price Index (Dec) Y/Y -0.6% (Prev. -0.1%)
